textline.text: MATTHEW A. ANDERSSON
DEPARTMENT OF SOCIOLOGY, YALE UNIVERSITY
P.O. BOX 208265, NEW HAVEN, CT 06520 matthew.andersson@yale.edu T: (203) 432-3216
EMPLOYMENT
Postdoctoral Associate
Center for Research on Inequalities and the Life Course (CIQLE)
Department of Sociology, Yale University
EDUCATION
2009-14 M.A. and Ph.D., Sociology. The University of Iowa.
Dissertation
Committee: Jennifer L. Glanville (Co-Chair), Steven Hitlin (Co-Chair), Sarah K. Harkness,
“Expecting Good Things and Feeling Good: A Sociological Approach to Health Inequalities.”
Freda B. Lynn, Robin W. Simon (Wake Forest University)
Qualifying Examinations
Social Stratification, Social Psychology
Health Inequality, Socioeconomic Status, Life Course, Social Networks, Family
2004-08 B.A., Chemistry, Psychology. Knox College, with Double College Thesis Honors. Phi Beta Kappa.

SELECTED HONORS
PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL ARTICLES
In Press Andersson, Matthew A. “The Long Arm of Warm Parenting: A Sex-Matching Perspective on
Kirschstein NICHD Research Service Award (UT-Austin Population Research Center) - Declined

ASA Social Psychology Graduate Student Paper Award
Honorable Mention, National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship

Valedictorian, Knox Class of 2008; National AP Scholar, National Merit Scholar
Adult Children's Physical Health.” Journal of Family Issues. Online article available.
Glass, Jennifer, Robin W. Simon and Matthew A. Andersson. "Parenthood and Happiness: Effects
of Work-Family Reconciliation Policies in 22 OECD Countries.” Conditionally accepted at
American Journal of Sociology.
Andersson, Matthew A. “How Do We Assign Ourselves Social Status? A Cross-Cultural Test of
the Cognitive Averaging Principle.” Social Science Research 52:317-329.
Andersson, Matthew A., Jennifer Glass and Robin W. Simon. “Users Beware! Variable Effects of
Parenthood on Happiness Within and Across International Datasets.” Social Indicators Research
Jennifer L. Glanville, Matthew A. Andersson and Pamela Paxton.1 “Do Social Connections Create
Trust? An Examination Using New Longitudinal Data.” Social Forces 92:545-562.
Andersson, Matthew A. and Colleen S. Conley. “Optimizing the Perceived Benefits and Health
Outcomes of Writing about Traumatic Life Events.” Stress and Health 29:40-49.
Coverage in Scientific American Mind (Nov/Dec 2013, p. 17)
Andersson, Matthew A. “Identity Crises in Love and at Work: Dispositional Optimism as a
Durable Personal Resource.” Social Psychology Quarterly 75:290-309.
Editorial Selection, SPQ Snaps; Podcast available at spq.sagepub.com
Andersson, Matthew A. “Dispositional Optimism and the Emergence of Social Network
Diversity.” Sociological Quarterly 53:92-115.
First Place, Social Science and Education, Jakobsen Research Conference, University of Iowa
Journal Impact Factor (2013): 6.75
Andersson, Matthew A. and Colleen S. Conley. “Expecting to Heal through Self-Expression: A
Perceived Control Theory of Writing and Health.” Health Psychology Review 2:138-162.
PEER-REVIEWED BOOK CHAPTERS
In Press Hitlin, Steven and Matthew A. Andersson. “Dignity as Moral Motivation: The Problem of Social
Order Writ Small.” Chapter 14 in Order on the Edge of Chaos: Social Psychology and the Problem
of Social Order, edited by Edward Lawler, Shane Thye and Jeongkoo Yoon. Introduction by Peter
V. Marsden. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.
Hitlin, Steven, Matthew A. Andersson and Glen H. Elder, Jr. “Motivation: Life Course and
Sociological Perspectives.” Pp. 940-945 in International Encyclopedia of Social and Behavioral
Sciences (2nd edition), Volume 15, edited by James D. Wright. Oxford: Elsevier.
Hitlin, Steven, and Matthew A Andersson. "Social Psychology of Human Dignity." Pp. 384-93 in
Handbook of Sociology and Human Rights, edited by David L Brunsma, Keri E. Iyall Smith, and
Brian K. Bran. London: Paradigm.

R&R
Andersson, Matthew A. “Chronic Disease at Midlife: Do Parent-Child Bonds Modify the Effect of
Childhood SES?” Journal of Health and Social Behavior.
Andersson, Matthew A. and Vida Maralani. “Early-Life Characteristics and Educational Disparities

R&R
Andersson, Matthew A. and Jennifer L. Glanville. “The Contingent Effects of Mental Well-Being

or Both? Unmet Needs and Work Interruption among Informal Elder Caregivers.”
R&R
Brazil, Noli and Andersson, Matthew A. “Social Comparison Goes to College: Mental Well-Being
and Peer Ability Change across the Postsecondary Transition.”

2013-14 Research Assistant, “Biographies of Scientific Ideas: The Diffusion of Knowledge in Medicine and

SELECTED PRESENTATIONS
Andersson, Matthew A. and Richard Breen. “When Do Identical Twins Differ on Education? A
Propensity Weighting Approach to Returns to Education.” Inequality and Life Course Workshop,
Department of Sociology, Yale University.
Andersson, Matthew A. “Parental Warmth and Children’s Postsecondary Education: College
Completion in Two Twentieth-Century Birth Cohorts (1921-1970).” Regular Session, Parental

Andersson, Matthew A. “Researching Health Inequalities using National Data.” Young Scholars
Program, Yale Center for Analytical Sciences.
Breen, Richard and Andersson, Matthew A. “The Changing Heritability of Education in the United
States.” Stratification Conference, Copenhagen.
Andersson, Matthew A. “Midlife Disease Burden and Combined Childhood Resources.” Program on
Aging Colloquium, Yale School of Medicine.
Brazil, Noli and Matthew A. Andersson. “Leaping from One Pond to Another: A Diagonal Mobility
Approach to Psychological Well-Being across the College Transition.” Session on Social Contexts

Andersson, Matthew A. and Vida Maralani. “Early-Life Characteristics and Emergent Educational
Disparities in Smoking.” Session on Education and Health Inequalities, PAA Meeting, San Diego.
Andersson, Matthew A. “How Do We Assign Ourselves Status? A Cross-Cultural Test of the
Cognitive Averaging Principle.” Comparative Research Workshop, Yale University.
Andersson, Matthew A. “A Dynamic Approach to Well-Being and Personal Social Networks.” Yale
Institute for Network Science. Nicholas Christakis, Director.
Andersson, Matthew A. “Thriving Under Autonomy: Optimism and Annual Worker Earnings.”
Organizations and Networks Brownbag, Department of Sociology, UMass - Amherst.
Andersson, Matthew A., Mark H. Walker and Brian P. Kaskie. “Activating Workplace Supports for
Informal Elder Caregiving.” Program on Aging Colloquium, Yale School of Medicine.
Andersson, Matthew A. “The Power of Love: Childhood Parental Warmth and the Leveling of
Educational Health Disparities.” Inequality and Life Course Workshop, Department of Sociology,
Yale University.
Andersson, Matthew A. “More than a Feeling: Emotional Well-Being and the Activation of
Education.” Social Psych. Brownbag, Univ. of Wisconsin - Madison. Alice Goffman, Organizer.
Jennifer Glass, Robin W. Simon and Matthew A. Andersson. “Parenthood and Happiness: Findings
from a Cross-National Study.” 2nd Work-Family Research Network Conference, Sydney, Australia.
Andersson, Matthew A. “Capitalizing on Education: Translating Education to Diverse Capitals via
Emotional Well-Being.” Regular Session, Emotions and Inequality, ASA Meeting, New York City.
Andersson, Matthew A. “The Social Psychology of Dignity.” Author Meets Critics Session for
Handbook of the Sociology of Human Rights, ASA Meeting, Denver, Colorado.
Jennifer L. Glanville, Matthew A. Andersson and Pamela Paxton. “Do Social Connections Create
Trust? A Longitudinal Analysis.” Session on Social Capital, ASA Meeting, Denver, Colorado.
Simon, Robin W., Jennifer Glass and Matthew A. Andersson. “The Impact of Parenthood on
Emotional and Physical Well-Being: Some Findings from a Study of 29 Nations.” The XIII

Andersson, Matthew A. “The Strain of Friendship: A Network-Based Approach to Self-Esteem and
Identity Change.” Session on Emotion and Identity Work, Midwest Sociological Society Annual

Andersson, Matthew A. “Defying Gravity: Optimism and the Emergence of Social Network
Diversity.” Social Psychology Roundtable, ASA Meeting, Las Vegas.
Andersson, Matthew A. “A Second Look at SN2: Alternative Mechanisms and Electrophilic
Heteroatoms.” Department of Chemistry, Knox College.
Andersson, Matthew A. “Can Writing Heal Writers? Investigating Psychophysiological Outcomes
of Expressive and Creative Types of Writing.” Poster Presented at the Midwestern Psychological
Association Annual Meeting, Chicago, Illinois.
Andersson, Matthew A. “Mood Disorders and Creative Writing.” Howard Hughes Medical Institute
Summer Research Forum, Knox College.
Rogers, Stephanie, John A. Haslem, Sharon Trotter-Martin and Matthew A. Andersson. 2006. “He
Actually Leaned Across the Table and Kissed Me: A Discussion of Gender and Sexual Dynamics.”
"Authority," 23rd National Conference on Peer Tutoring, Sweetland Center, University of Michigan.
